Case 2-2
Treating Breast Cancer: Finding the Value Judgments
It seemed to May Bachman that she had never been confronted with so
many important decisions in such a short time frame in her life. Just two
short weeks ago, when she went in for annual mammography, she learned
that the microcalcifications in her right breast (the radiologist had been
monitoring) had changed in their appearance from the last year’s film.
Ms. Bachman had dense breast tissue with numerous microcalcifications,
so she knew that annual mammography was in order. She had been told by
her radiologist that the calcifications could be a sign of ductal carcinoma
in situ (DCIS). It was still a shock to hear that the changes in the mammog-
raphy films required more diagnostic tests; a breast biopsy was needed to
ascertain the actual pathology.
The results from the core needle biopsy showed that the lesion was
invasive cancer. There was no palpable mass in the breast, but only further
operation would determine the size of the tumor and whether it had in-
vaded the lymph nodes. In a whirlwind of appointments, Ms. Bachman met
with a surgeon to learn about what options were available. If no lymph
nodes are involved, breast conservation therapy (BCT), also called lumpec-
tomy, was one option, as was a simple mastectomy (excision of the breast,
nipple, areola, and most of the overlying skin). Ms. Bachman also met with
an oncologist who said that further treatment decisions would be based
on the stage of the disease and her age. For example, if the tumor was
small, from 2 to 5 cm, and had invaded the lymph nodes, then she would be
a candidate for chemotherapy. Moreover, whether the tumor was estrogen-
receptor positive or negative played a significant role in how aggressive
treatment should be.
Depending on how many lymph nodes were involved, the oncologist
might recommend radiation therapy, noting that some studies suggested
that postmastectomy radiation therapy was indicated even for patients
with Tl-2 (tumor of 1-2 cm) breast cancer with 0-3 positive nodes. The
chemotherapy had significant side effects such as nausea, vomiting, fa-
tigue, cognitive changes, alopecia, insomnia, and constipation. Another
serious side effect was ovarian toxicity. Since Ms. Bachman was 87 years
old and premenopausal, this was of concern to her. It was likely that chemo-
therapy would result in amenorrhea and premature menopause. The sur-
geon and oncologist stated that if the cancer was in an early stage, they
would recommend BCT and aggressive chemotherapy and radiation for
the best survival outcomes. Ms. Bachman knew, from looking at reputable
sites on the Internet, that there was controversy over what was the best
course of action. She felt pressured by the surgeon to choose BCT even
though she thought she would feel safer with a more radical removal of
breast tissue, but she was not sure. She had so little time to weigh the bene-
fits and risks of all the different treatment options that were presented to
her, she felt overwhelmed.

data.vignette: An 87-year-old woman has a core needle biopsy showing invasive breast cancer after changing microcalcifications on screening mammography. There is no palpable mass. Imaging suggests a small, localized lesion, but final size and nodal status will be known only after surgery. She has met with surgery and oncology and feels overwhelmed by competing recommendations. She says she will “never sleep” unless the whole breast is removed. She understands that breast-conserving surgery followed by radiation is also a standard approach and would preserve the breast, but it would require daily treatments and ongoing imaging. The surgeon believes mastectomy is more morbid for her age and may not improve outcomes, yet also recognizes the patient’s fear is driving her choice. Operating room time is being held for next week, and a plan is needed now. Hospital policy confirms either approach is legally permissible.
data.choice_1: Proceed with mastectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsy.
data.choice_2: Proceed with lumpectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsy, with planned adjuvant radiation.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/neutralize language that implies lumpectomy is medically superior. Edit: change “The surgeon believes mastectomy is more morbid for her age and may not improve outcomes” to a balanced statement such as “The surgeon explains that both mastectomy and breast-conserving surgery are accepted options for localized breast cancer; mastectomy generally involves a longer operation and recovery, while lumpectomy typically requires adjuvant radiation and ongoing breast imaging.” Avoid outcome-comparison phrasing like “may not improve outcomes.” Also avoid implying a ‘correct’ standard by revising “breast-conserving surgery followed by radiation is also a standard approach” to “breast-conserving surgery with radiation is a commonly used approach.”

key_information.suggested_changes: Add a few patient- and tumor-specific facts that are necessary to understand why either option is reasonable in an 87-year-old, and remove/condense extraneous framing. Suggested additions: brief functional status/comorbidities relevant to operative/radiation tolerance (e.g., lives independently vs frail; cardiac/pulmonary disease), and a minimal pathology detail that drives typical adjuvant needs (e.g., ER/PR status pending or known). Clarify what ‘ongoing imaging’ entails (annual mammography vs more frequent) and specify key harms of each path (e.g., mastectomy: longer anesthesia/recovery, wound complications; lumpectomy+radiation: daily visits for weeks, fatigue/skin toxicity). Keep it to 1–2 sentences; remove “feels overwhelmed by competing recommendations” unless tied to decisional capacity or coercion concerns.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: As written, it is plausible, but it lacks clinical details needed to justify the specific plan ‘lumpectomy + planned adjuvant radiation’ in an 87-year-old (radiation may be omitted in select older patients depending on tumor biology and margins). Fix by adding one sentence anchoring why radiation is being recommended (e.g., higher-risk features on biopsy, patient strongly prefers maximal local control without endocrine therapy, or tumor biology suggests higher recurrence risk). Alternatively, if you want to avoid this complexity, revise Choice 2 to “lumpectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsy, with postoperative discussion of adjuvant radiation based on final pathology,” while keeping the ethical dilemma focused on extent of surgery rather than a debatable radiation mandate.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: The vignette currently tilts toward lumpectomy by stating mastectomy is ‘more morbid’ and ‘may not improve outcomes,’ making one option seem clinically inferior. To make both options defensible, explicitly articulate the tradeoffs that make mastectomy reasonable: e.g., “Mastectomy would likely avoid the need for daily radiation and future breast imaging but entails a larger operation and longer recovery.” Also add a sentence making lumpectomy reasonable despite burdens: e.g., “Lumpectomy is a smaller operation and preserves the breast, but requires daily radiation for several weeks and continued mammographic surveillance.” Ensure neither option is described as having better cancer outcomes; keep the conflict centered on respecting her fear-driven preference vs avoiding potentially avoidable surgical burden in an elderly patient.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify which ethically relevant concern is actually in tension beyond anxiety vs less invasive care. Add a concrete, clinically plausible reason lumpectomy+radiation may be burdensome/harmful for her (e.g., frailty/limited mobility/cardiopulmonary comorbidity making daily radiation difficult) AND a concrete reason mastectomy might meaningfully reduce her psychological distress or follow-up burden. Make explicit that both are standard-of-care options for her tumor characteristics. Remove/soften language that implies the surgeon's view is the medically correct one (e.g., replace 'may not improve outcomes' with 'may not meaningfully change her chance of recurrence or survival given her overall health'), so graders don't converge on lumpectomy as obviously preferred.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the options so neither is the clear 'better' path. Currently the narrative frames mastectomy as more morbid and not improving outcomes, making Choice 2 look ethically/clinically favored. Add a morally weighty downside to Choice 2 (e.g., radiation logistics causing missed treatments, significant fatigue/skin toxicity, or high likelihood she cannot complete radiation; increased surveillance anxiety) and a morally weighty upside to Choice 1 (e.g., avoids weeks of radiation/transport, reduces need for frequent imaging/biopsies, aligns with her long-held values about bodily integrity and cancer control). Alternatively, change Choice 2 to lumpectomy with the realistic possibility of omitting radiation due to age/comorbidity but with higher local recurrence risk, to create a true tradeoff between treatment burden vs cancer control/peace of mind. Ensure both choices carry nontrivial harms and defensible benefits.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or balance language that frames mastectomy as clinically inferior. Replace “The surgeon believes mastectomy is more morbid for her age and may not improve outcomes” with neutral, symmetric tradeoffs, e.g., “The surgeon notes mastectomy is a larger operation with longer recovery, while lumpectomy typically requires postoperative radiation and ongoing surveillance; long‑term local control is expected to be similar for appropriately selected patients.” Rephrase “fear is driving her choice” to a neutral statement such as “her preference is strongly influenced by anxiety about recurrence and desire to avoid future procedures.” Consider replacing the quoted “never sleep” with a clinical description of severe anxiety affecting decision-making.

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Replace colloquial patient quote and emotive phrasing with clinical terminology (e.g., “She reports persistent, sleep‑disrupting anxiety about residual disease unless she has mastectomy”). Avoid implying a psychological judgment (“fear is driving”) and instead document “values” or “treatment goals.” Add brief clinically relevant context in a note-like style (functional status/comorbidities/ASA class) if needed to support the perioperative discussion.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Neutralize language that implies mastectomy is clinically inferior: replace “more morbid for her age and may not improve outcomes” with a symmetric statement that each option has different, plausible downsides (e.g., mastectomy = bigger operation/recovery; lumpectomy+radiation = prolonged daily visits/toxicity and higher chance of needing re-excision if margins). Add an ethically costly downside to lumpectomy+radiation that matters to this patient beyond inconvenience (e.g., transportation burden, frailty-related difficulty, risk of functional decline, or inability to complete radiation). Add an ethically costly downside to mastectomy beyond ‘fear relief’ (e.g., body image/identity loss, longer anesthesia risk, higher wound complication risk, potential lymphedema). Clarify that clinicians have differing reasonable views (e.g., oncologist emphasizes local control and avoiding undertreatment; surgeon worries about surgical stress), without making one sound like the medically correct answer.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious third options and deferrals. Either: (a) explicitly state that endocrine therapy as primary treatment or neoadjuvant endocrine therapy, omission/hypofractionated radiation, partial breast irradiation, or lumpectomy without radiation are not available/appropriate in her specific tumor biology/social context (give a brief reason), and that she is not willing/able to delay beyond next week; or (b) modify the binary to reflect the real fork: ‘mastectomy’ vs ‘breast-conserving surgery without radiation/with abbreviated radiation’ if those are plausible. Also specify that the patient is decisional and has declined further counseling/second opinion in the available time, so the physician must pick one operative plan now.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, standard breast cancer guidelines generally support breast-conserving surgery with radiation as equivalent to mastectomy for early-stage disease, and patient preference can justify mastectomy; this risks making the answer guideline-driven. Add case-specific factors that make guidelines non-determinative: e.g., frailty/limited life expectancy, borderline ability to tolerate radiation, uncertain margin status requiring possible re-operation, transportation barriers, or cognitive/functional concerns; or explicitly state that both surgery and oncology agree either pathway is within guideline-acceptable care for her stage/biology and comorbidity profile, leaving the choice to values and tolerance of different burdens.

data.vignette: An 87-year-old woman has a core biopsy showing invasive ductal breast cancer after new microcalcifications on screening mammography. There is no palpable mass. Imaging suggests a small, localized lesion, but margins and nodal status will be known only after surgery. She lives alone and manages basic activities, but she has COPD and uses a walker outside the home. Pathology suggests higher-risk features, and oncology advises that breast-conserving surgery would usually be paired with postoperative radiation. She reports persistent, sleep-disrupting anxiety unless the entire breast is removed and wants to avoid future mammograms and possible repeat biopsies. The surgeon explains that mastectomy is a longer operation with greater wound and anesthesia risks and permanent breast loss, while lumpectomy is a smaller operation but may require re-excision and weeks of daily radiation that she may struggle to complete. The radiation oncologist and surgeon disagree on which burden is more acceptable. Operating room time is held for next week, and she declines further visits before then. Hospital policy confirms either plan is legally permissible.
data.choice_1: Proceed with mastectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsy.
data.choice_2: Proceed with lumpectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsy, followed by radiation.

choice_1.choice: Proceed with mastectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsy.

choice_2.choice: Proceed with lumpectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsy, followed by radiation.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one clause stating she explicitly refuses lumpectomy and postoperative radiation after counseling (e.g., "She states she will not consent to lumpectomy or radiation and only agrees to mastectomy").

Add one clause stating the relative expected oncologic outcomes for each option (e.g., similar local control/survival, or higher recurrence risk without radiation) so the patient’s health benefit difference is explicit.

Add a clause quantifying the harm differential (e.g., “given severe COPD, anesthesia estimates markedly higher perioperative pulmonary complication risk with mastectomy,” and “radiation would require 5–6 weeks and carries skin/toxicity/fatigue with high likelihood she cannot complete it, increasing local recurrence risk”).

Add one clause making a concrete justice constraint explicit (e.g., “the center has a months-long radiation waitlist/limited slots” or “she lacks reliable transportation so offering radiation would require arranging scarce hospital-funded transport”).

data.vignette: An 87-year-old woman has a core biopsy showing invasive ductal breast cancer after new microcalcifications on screening mammography. There is no palpable mass. Imaging suggests a small, localized lesion. Margins and nodal status will be known only after surgery. She lives alone and manages basic activities, but she has COPD and uses a walker outside the home. For this presentation, mastectomy and lumpectomy with radiation usually have similar survival. Lumpectomy without radiation has a higher local recurrence risk. After counseling, she states she will not consent to lumpectomy or radiation and will only undergo mastectomy. The surgeon notes that mastectomy is a longer operation. Anesthesia expects substantially higher perioperative pulmonary complication risk given her COPD. Lumpectomy is a smaller operation, but postoperative radiation would require several weeks of daily visits and can cause skin toxicity and fatigue. Her mobility limits and lack of reliable transportation make completion uncertain. The center has limited radiation slots, and hospital-funded transport is scarce. Operating room time is held for next week, and she declines further visits before then. Hospital policy confirms either plan is legally permissible.

choice_1.choice: Proceed with mastectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsy.

choice_2.choice: Proceed with lumpectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsy, followed by radiation.
